sections.title: Explore Beyond Traditional Assets
sections.subtitle: Evaluate private equity, real estate, commodities, and more to diversify your portfolio

sections.title: Key Learning Points
items: Define what qualifies as an alternative investment
Weigh benefits and risks of major categories
Understand liquidity, fees, and due diligence requirements
Decide when alternatives fit your personal strategy

sections.title: Why Consider Alternatives?
sections.content: Alternatives can provide diversification, inflation protection, and potential for higher returns. They often have lower correlation with public markets, reducing portfolio volatility when used appropriately.

points.title: Private Equity & Venture Capital
points.description: Investments in private companies, offering high growth potential with long lock-up periods.

points.title: Real Assets
points.description: Real estate, infrastructure, and commodities provide tangible exposure often tied to inflation.

points.title: Hedge Funds
points.description: Pooled strategies using leverage, derivatives, or long/short positions to seek absolute returns.

points.title: Collectibles & Digital Assets
points.description: Art, wine, crypto, and other niche assets—highly speculative and require specialized knowledge.

sections.title: Due Diligence Required
sections.content: Alternatives demand deeper research, often higher minimums, and careful attention to liquidity constraints.

sections.title: Risks & Considerations
sections.content: Higher fees, limited transparency, and regulatory differences make alternatives unsuitable for many investors. Ensure you understand valuation methods, exit strategies, and tax implications before investing.

sections.title: Alternatives Evaluation Checklist
steps: Confirm your core portfolio (public stocks/bonds) is aligned with long-term goals before adding alternatives.
Define your allocation limit—typically 5–15% of net investable assets for experienced investors.
Research at least two alternative investment opportunities and list expected returns, fees, liquidity terms, and minimum investment.
Assess how each option interacts with your existing holdings (correlation, diversification benefits).
Consult with a fiduciary advisor or conduct a comprehensive due diligence review before committing capital.

sections.title: Start with Access Vehicles
sections.content: Consider publicly traded REITs, commodity ETFs, or interval funds to gain exposure with better liquidity.
